utterances: Unidentified Woman #9: I think it was very easy.

It doesn't matter who you vote for, as long as you vote.
And please be educated about voting.
And don't believe all the lies you hear.

I think today we're going to write another page of the story.

Republican, we're going to have a woman vice president, Democratic, we're going to have an African-American - half African-American half white.
So we're going make history.
So I'm sure it's that.

Everybody get up.
If you can go to the club and do everything else, get up go vote, we could party afterwards.

We heard from Heather Biliot (ph) in Dulac, Louisiana, Ernestine (ph) and Augustus (ph) in Harlem, New York, Anita Bonvianne (ph) in Dulac, Louisiana, Darnell Durval (ph) in Flatbush, Brooklyn, Avis Anderson (ph) in Washington, D.C.
and Albunis Saliman (ph) in Brooklyn, New York.
Plus Amanda Parfait (ph) in Dulac, Louisiana.
With a special thanks to reporters from People's Production House.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Columbus.
Big Bird bows out; a big bounce for the GOP; and Romney recalculates that 47 percent.

Completely wrong.
Edition of the Political Junkie.

When I hear your new ideas, I'm reminded of that ad: Where's the beef?
Extremism in the defense of liberty is no vice.
Senator, you're no Jack Kennedy.
You don't have Nixon to kick around anymore.
Lipstick.
Oops.
But I'm the decider.

Every Wednesday, Political Junkie Ken Rudin joins us to recap the week in politics.
Today, we're both in the critical swing state of Ohio at the studios of member station WOSU in Columbus.
After last week's debate, polls show Romney eroded, erased or even reversed the president's lead.
Tomorrow, veep Joe Biden tries to stop the bleeding as he squares off against Paul Ryan in Danville, Kentucky.
Ann Romney co-hosts GMA, ""Sesame Street"" declines a spot on the front lines.
In a few minutes, a snapshot of the Buckeye State a month out.
Later in the program, we'll focus on the Senate race in Virginia, which features two former governors and which may decide which party controls the U.S.
Senate.
But first, Political Junkie Ken Rudin joins us here in the studios at WOSU, and Ken: A, welcome back Ohio; and B, we begin, as usual, with a trivia question.
Hello, Columbus, exactly.
OK, so we're in Ohio, and the baseball playoffs are underway, right Neal?
And tomorrow is the vice presidential debate.
So here's a trivia question that combines them all.
Let's see if this...
Really?
OK.
Let's see if this works the way every other one works.
Which vice president was elected the same year a professional sports team from Ohio, be it baseball, football, basketball or hockey, last won a championship?
George, Robert and Laura, thank you so much and happy holidays to you all.
Appreciate it.
Even as more readers log on to newspaper Web sites, those sites rarely earn the newspapers much money.
Stephen Lacy teaches media economics at Michigan State University.
The numbers of visits and hits, etcetera, page views, are going up at newspapers.
The problem is when they sell advertising online, they're getting nickels instead of dollars.
The print editions of the Detroit News and Detroit Free Press are unlikely to go away entirely under the plan now being discussed by managers.
It's expected that a scaled-down print edition will still be available at newsstands.
For NPR News, I'm Noah Ovshinsky in Detroit.
This is Don Gonyea traveling with the McCain campaign.
The argument over Obama's lipstick line did not play a role in Senator McCain's public events yesterday in Lancaster, Pennsylvania or in Lebanon, Ohio.
At the Ohio rally, there stood McCain, Governor Sarah Palin, and her husband, Todd, someone whom the man at the top of ticket singled out for extended praise and for some symbolism.

This great American, her husband, Todd Palin, I'm telling you, 2,000 miles in a snowmobile in the middle of winter in 40 degrees below zero, this guy can take on anything Washington can hand out, I'll tell you that right now.
(Soundbite of applause)
As he does in most every speech, McCain talked about Iraq.
On this day, his speech to an outdoor audience in small town Ohio coincided with a speech President Bush was giving in Washington at the exact same time about U.S.
troop levels in Iraq.
Mr.
Bush, in his speech, announced plans for a small force reduction - some 8,000 troops - by February.
That's after a new president has been sworn in.
The McCain campaign reacted with a written statement, praising the president's decision and calling it a sign of success.
In his speeches yesterday, McCain did not mention the president or the White House plan to reduce troop levels, but he did repeat his upbeat assessment of the situation in Iraq.
Thanks to General David Petraeus and these brave young Americans, we are winning in Iraq and we will come home with honor.
(Soundbite of applause)
Then followed with this direct assault on Obama.
Senator Obama was wrong about Iran, he was wrong about Iraq, he was wrong about Russia.
He's wrong about America's national security challenges in the future, and he has no experience and more importantly he lacks the judgment to lead this country.
The Obama campaign counters that it was McCain who was wrong - for supporting the push to go to war in the first place.
During her crowd-pleasing portion of the rally, Governor Palin including her own very positive assessment of how the Iraq war is going.
In doing so, referencing another member of her family, her son, Track, who is scheduled to deploy to Iraq soon.
John McCain refused to break faith with the troops who have now brought victory within sight.
And as the mother of one of those troops, he's exactly the kind of man I want as commander-in-chief.
(Soundbite of applause)
Neither Palin nor McCain offered any specifics on U.S.
troop levels in Iraq, nor did their speeches include any mention of just how ready the Iraqi government is to take over security of the country, or when that might occur.
Both call for the U.S.
to stay on the offensive in Iraq, even as they try to keep Obama on the defensive regarding the war.
McCain and Palin have been touring together since the GOP convention last week.
That will come to an end, at least for a while, today.
Governor Palin heads home to Alaska this afternoon.
McCain, meanwhile, will be out on the stump on his own, where he'll find out if the big crowds continue to show up for him alone.
Don Gonyea, NPR News.
And as the candidates travel this week, we've been listening to what voters are saying about this election and race.
Tomorrow we'll be listening to some voters describe their own experiences.
Unidentified Woman #1: I don't pretend to understand the plight of African-American of Hispanic or any other nationality that's not my own.
And I honestly want to understand.
And I guarantee you, I have still seen it.
I'm not a blind black man.
I do see what happens when I walk into certain stores.
Unidentified Woman #2: I was in my 20s before I ever realized that black people didn't have everything I had.
The voices of a diverse group of voters gathered at a Pennsylvania hotel.
My co-host, Steve Inskeep, was there.
